chat_history.content: Are the materials price and quantity variances recorded in the same journal entry?

That's a practical question about how these variances impact accounting records. What do you think the purpose of separating these variances into different journal entries might be, considering how they affect different parts of the income statement?

The materials price variance affects the cost of goods sold, while the materials quantity variance affects the cost of goods sold and the gross margin. Separating them helps in better analysis and control.

That’s a good start! You’re right about the impact on the income statement and the benefit of analysis. But could separating them into different journal entries also relate to *who* is responsible for addressing each type of variance – and how might that influence recording them separately?

Separating them into different journal entries can help identify who is responsible for each variance. For example, the purchasing department might be responsible for price variances, while the production department might be responsible for quantity variances. This separation allows for better accountability and control.

That’s a very insightful connection between responsibility and accounting! Now, thinking about the actual journal entries, how would recording both variances in a single entry affect your ability to quickly pinpoint which department needs to address a specific issue?

Recording both variances in a single entry would make it harder to quickly pinpoint which department needs to address a specific issue. It would blur the lines of responsibility and make it more difficult to analyze and control the variances effectively.

You've clearly grasped the core reason for separate recording – maintaining clear accountability. Do you think this principle of separating variances extends to other types of variances, like labor rate and labor efficiency variances, and why might that be?

Yes, the principle of separating variances extends to other types of variances, like labor rate and labor efficiency variances. This separation helps in identifying the responsible departments and allows for better analysis and control. For example, the human resources department might be responsible for labor rate variances, while the production department might be responsible for labor efficiency variances. This way, each department can focus on addressing the issues within their control. Thank you for the explanation.

seed.source_content:
Learning Objectives
• Explain the difference between homologous and analogous structures

Two Options for Similarities

In general, organisms that share similar physical features and genomes tend to be more closely related than those that do not. Such features that overlap both morphologically (in form) and genetically are referred to as homologous structures; they stem from developmental similarities that are based on evolution. For example, the bones in the wings of bats and birds have homologous structures.

Notice it is not simply a single bone, but rather a grouping of several bones arranged in a similar way. The more complex the feature, the more probable that any overlap is due to a common evolutionary past. Imagine two people from different countries both inventing a car with all the same parts and in exactly the same arrangement without any previous or shared knowledge. That outcome would be highly improbable. However, if two people both invented a hammer, it would be reasonable to conclude that both could have the original idea without the help of the other. The same relationship between complexity and shared evolutionary history is true for homologous structures in organisms.

Misleading Appearances

Some organisms may be very closely related, even though a minor genetic change caused a major morphological difference to make them look quite different. Similarly, unrelated organisms may be distantly related, but appear very similar. This usually happens because both organisms developed common adaptations that evolved within similar environmental conditions. When similar characteristics occur because of environmental constraints and not due to a close evolutionary relationship, it is called an analogy or homoplasy. For example, insects use wings to fly like bats and birds, but the wing structure and embryonic origin is completely different. These are called analogous structures.

Similar traits can be either homologous or analogous. Homologous structures share a similar embryonic origin; analogous organs have a similar function. For example, the bones in the front flipper of a whale are homologous to the bones in the human arm. These structures are not analogous. The wings of a butterfly and the wings of a bird are analogous, but not homologous. Some structures are both analogous and homologous: the wings of a bird and the wings of a bat are both homologous and analogous. Scientists must determine which type of similarity a feature exhibits to decipher the phylogeny of the organisms being studied.

Molecular Comparisons

With the advancement of DNA technology, the area of molecular systematics, which describes the use of information on the molecular level including DNA analysis, has blossomed. New computer programs not only confirm many earlier classified organisms, but also uncover previously-made errors. As with physical characteristics, even the DNA sequence can be tricky to read in some cases. For some situations, two very closely-re

chat_history.content: Are the wings of a butterfly and a bird homologous because they both have the same function?

That's a great starting point! Function can certainly *seem* like a key similarity. But is shared function enough to determine if structures are truly homologous? What else might you consider when determining if two structures share a common evolutionary origin?
The structures should have a common evolutionary origin.

That’s right! Common evolutionary origin is key. But how would you *determine* if two structures share a common evolutionary origin, especially when looking at organisms that live today? What kind of evidence might support that claim?
We could look at the genetic and developmental similarities between the structures.
Excellent! Genetic and developmental similarities are strong lines of evidence. But how might differences in those areas – even with functional similarities – suggest a different evolutionary path?
If the structures have different genetic and developmental origins, they might have evolved independently for similar functions, which would make them analogous rather than homologous.

That’s a very insightful distinction! So, considering what we’ve discussed about butterfly and bird wings – and focusing on their underlying structure, development, and genetics – do you think they are homologous, analogous, or something else? Why?
They are analogous. They evolved independently for similar functions.

That's a reasonable conclusion based on our discussion! Can you elaborate on *why* you believe the developmental and genetic evidence points towards analogous structures rather than homologous ones in this case?

The wings of butterflies and birds are analogous because they evolved independently from different ancestral structures. Butterfly wings are modified from the exoskeleton of insects, while bird wings are modified forelimbs. The genetic and developmental pathways that lead to the formation of these wings are distinct, reflecting their different evolutionary histories.

That’s a clear and well-reasoned explanation! It demonstrates a good grasp of the difference between homologous and analogous structures. Would you be interested in exploring how these concepts apply to other examples, perhaps even some that are more subtle or debated among scientists?
I would like to explore more examples of homologous and analogous structures.

Great! Let's consider the human arm, a bat's wing, and a whale's flipper. All three serve very different functions – grasping, flying, and swimming, respectively. However, if you were to examine the skeletal structure of each, you'd find striking similarities. How might this combination of different functions *and* similar underlying structure help us determine if these structures are homologous or analogous?

The similarities in skeletal structure suggest that these are homologous structures, as they share a common evolutionary origin despite their different functions. This is an example of how homologous structures can evolve to serve different purposes in different organisms.

That’s a solid interpretation! You’ve correctly identified how similar underlying structure points towards homology. Now, considering that these structures *have* diverged to perform different functions, what might studying the *genes* responsible for limb development reveal about how these changes occurred? Would you expect to find significant differences or similarities in those genes, and what would that tell you?

I would expect to find similarities in the genes responsible for limb development, as these structures are homologous. The differences in function would likely be due to variations in gene expression or regulation rather than fundamental differences in the genes themselves. This would support the idea that these structures share a common evolutionary origin but have adapted to different functions over time.

That’s a very insightful prediction! Variations in gene expression and regulation are often key to driving evolutionary changes while maintaining the underlying genetic blueprint. Now, let's push this a bit further. Imagine you discovered a gene that's *completely absent* in the whale lineage but is crucial for limb development in humans and bats. How would that finding impact your understanding of the evolutionary relationship between these structures?

It would suggest that the whale's flipper might have evolved through a different genetic pathway, potentially indicating convergent evolution rather than homology. This would challenge the idea of a common evolutionary origin for these structures and suggest that they might be analogous instead.

That's a very astute observation! The absence of a key developmental gene would certainly cast doubt on a simple homologous relationship. However, evolution doesn't always leave a perfectly clear trail. Could there be other explanations for the absence of that gene – perhaps it was duplicated and then lost function in the whale lineage, or maybe another gene took over its role? How might you investigate those possibilities?

We could look at the genetic and developmental pathways in more detail to see if there are any signs of gene duplication or functional shifts. Additionally, comparing the expression patterns of related genes in whales, humans, and bats might provide insights into how the flipper evolved. This would involve studying the molecular systematics and developmental biology of these organisms to better understand their evolutionary relationships. Thank you for the help.

seed.source_content:
The Nature of Mass Spectra

A mass spectrum will usually be presented as a vertical bar graph, in which each bar represents an ion having a specific mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) and the length of the bar indicates the relative abundance of the ion. The most intense ion is assigned an abundance of 100, and it is referred to as the base peak. Most of the ions formed in a mass spectrometer have a single charge, so the m/z value is equivalent to mass itself. Modern mass spectrometers easily distinguish (resolve) ions differing by only a single atomic mass unit, and thus provide completely accurate values for the molecular mass of a compound. The highest-mass ion in a spectrum is normally considered to be the molecular ion, and lower-mass ions are fragments from the molecular ion, assuming the sample is a single pure compound.

Atomic mass is given in terms of the unified atomic mass unit (symbol: μ) or dalton (symbol: Da). In recent years there has been a gradual change towards using the dalton in preference to the unified atomic mass unit. The dalton is classified as a "non-SI unit whose values in SI units must be obtained experimentally". It is defined as one twelfth of the rest mass of an unbound atom of carbon-12 in its nuclear and electronic ground state, and has a value of 1.660538782(83)x10-27 kg.

The following diagram displays the mass spectra of three simple gaseous compounds, carbon dioxide, propane and cyclopropane. The molecules of these compounds are similar in size, CO2 and C3H8 both have a nominal mass of 44 Da, and C3H6 has a mass of 42 Da. The molecular ion is the strongest ion in the spectra of CO2 and C3H6, and it is moderately strong in propane. The unit mass resolution is readily apparent in these spectra (note the separation of ions having m/z=39, 40, 41 and 42 in the cyclopropane spectrum). Even though these compounds are very similar in size, it is a simple matter to identify them from their individual mass spectra. By clicking on each spectrum in turn, a partial fragmentation analysis and peak assignment will be displayed. Even with simple compounds like these, it should be noted that it is rarely possible to explain the origin of all the fragment ions in a spectrum. Also, the structure of most fragment ions is seldom known with certainty.

Since a molecule of carbon dioxide is composed of only three atoms, its mass spectrum is very simple. The molecular ion is also the base peak, and the only fragment ions are CO (m/z=28) and O (m/z=16). The molecular ion of propane also has m/z=44, but it is not the most abundant ion in the spectrum. Cleavage of a carbon-carbon bond gives methyl and ethyl fragments, one of which is a carbocation and the other a radical. Both distributions are observed, but the larger ethyl cation (m/z=29) is the most abundant, possibly because its size affords greater charge dispersal. A similar bond cleavage in cyclopropane does not give two fragments, so the molecular ion is stronger than in propane, and i

That's a great question! Mass spectrometry provides a wealth of information, but interpreting the data can seem daunting at first. To start, what do you think the data *represents* – what is actually being measured by the instrument?
The data represents the mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) of ions.

That’s correct! The mass-to-charge ratio is fundamental to understanding the data. Now, considering that different molecules will have different m/z values, how do you think the *intensity* of a signal at a specific m/z relates to the sample itself?
The intensity of a signal at a specific m/z indicates the abundance of ions with that particular mass-to-charge ratio in the sample. Higher intensity means more of those ions are present.

That’s a very good understanding! So, if you were looking at a mass spectrum of a simple molecule, what would you expect to see – specifically, what kind of peaks would you anticipate, and what would they tell you about the molecule?

I would expect to see a peak corresponding to the molecular ion, which represents the whole molecule. Additionally, there would be fragment ions, which are pieces of the molecule that have broken off. The pattern of these peaks can help identify the structure of the molecule.

That’s a solid explanation! You’ve grasped the core concepts of how fragmentation patterns aid in structural identification. 

Now, let’s consider a slightly more complex scenario. What factors might cause a molecule to fragment in *different* ways within the mass spectrometer, leading to variations in the observed fragment ion peaks?

The energy applied to the molecule, the structure of the molecule, and the type of mass spectrometer used can all influence how a molecule fragments. For example, higher energy can cause more extensive fragmentation.

Learning Objectives

At the end of this section, students should be able to meet the following objectives:

1. Explain the need for an adjusting entry in the reporting of prepaid expenses and be able to prepare that adjustment.
2. Explain the need for an adjusting entry in the reporting of accrued revenue and be able to prepare that adjustment.
3. Describe the difficulty of determining when the earning process for revenue is substantially complete and discuss possible resolutions.

Question: The second adjustment to be considered here involves the handling ofprepaid expenses. In the transactions that were recorded in the previous chapter, Journal Entry 10 reported a \$4,000 payment made in advance for four months of rent to use a building. An asset—prepaid rent—was recorded through the normal accounting process. This account is listed on the trial balance in Figure 5.1 “Updated Trial Balance”. Why might a year-end adjusting entry be needed in connection with a prepaid expense?

Answer: During these four months, the Lawndale Company will use the rented facility to help generate revenue. Over that time, the future economic benefit established by the payment gradually becomes a past benefit. The asset literally changes into an expense day by day. For illustrative purposes, assume that one month has now passed since the original payment. This month of benefit provided by the rent (\$1,000 or \$4,000/four months) no longer exists; it has been consumed.

As a preliminary step in preparing financial statements, an adjusting entry is needed to reclassify \$1,000 from the asset into an expense account. This adjustment leaves \$3,000 in the asset (for the remaining three months of rent on the building) while \$1,000 is now reported as an expense (for the previous one month of rent).

The basic purpose of adjusting entries is to take whatever amounts reside in the ledger and align them with the requirements of U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (U.S. GAAP). For this illustration, the original \$4,000 payment was classified as a prepaid rent and the adjustment above was created in response to that initial entry.

In recording transactions, some accounting systems mechanically handle events in a different manner than others. Thus, construction of an adjusting entry always depends on the recording that previously took place. To illustrate, assume that when this \$4,000 payment was made, the company’s computer program had been designed to enter a debit to rent expense rather than to prepaid rent. All money spent for rent was automatically recorded as rent expense. This initial accounting has no impact on the final figures to be reported but does alter the adjustment process.

An adjusting entry still needs to be prepared so that the expense appearing on the income statement is \$1,000 (for the past one month) while the asset on the balance sheet is shown as \$3,000 (for the next three months). If the entire cost of \$4,000 is in rent expense, the fol

chat_history.content: Are prepaid expenses always recorded as expenses immediately when paid?

That's a great question! It gets to the heart of how we match expenses to the periods they benefit. What do you think would happen if we *always* recorded a payment as an expense right away, regardless of when the benefit was received?
We would be recording expenses in the wrong period.
Exactly. And why is recording expenses in the wrong period a problem for those who rely on financial statements – like investors or lenders?
It would give them an inaccurate picture of the company's financial health. They might think the company is spending more than it actually is in a given period, which could affect their decisions.
That's a very insightful point. So, if simply recording the cash outflow isn't enough, what characteristic of the *benefit* received needs to be considered when deciding how to account for it?
The benefit received should be matched with the period in which it is used or consumed.

That’s the core principle! Now, can you think of a situation where a company pays for something *before* they actually receive the benefit? And how would recording that payment immediately misrepresent the company’s financial performance?

A company might pay for insurance premiums upfront for a full year. If we record the entire payment as an expense immediately, it would make the current period's expenses look much higher than they actually are for the operations of that period. Instead, we should recognize the expense gradually over the year as the insurance benefit is used.

You've clearly grasped the concept of matching expenses to the periods they benefit! It sounds like you understand *why* prepaid expenses aren’t immediately expensed.

Now, let's think about the mechanics. What specific account would you use to initially record that upfront payment for insurance, *before* recognizing it as an expense?
We would record the upfront payment as an asset, specifically as "Prepaid Insurance."

That’s correct! “Prepaid Insurance” is indeed the appropriate asset account. 

Now, let’s consider what happens over time. As the company *uses* the insurance coverage, how would you adjust the accounts to reflect the portion of the insurance that has been “used up” during a specific period? What accounts would be affected, and how (increase or decrease)?

We would make an adjusting entry to record the portion of the prepaid insurance that has been used up as an expense. We would debit "Insurance Expense" and credit "Prepaid Insurance." This way, we recognize the expense in the correct period and reduce the prepaid asset accordingly.

Excellent! You’ve accurately described the adjusting entry. 

Now, let’s shift gears slightly. Imagine a scenario where a company *underestimates* the amount of prepaid expense that needs to be recognized at the end of the accounting period. How would this error impact the financial statements in both the current and future periods? Would it be an overstatement or understatement of net income, and why?

If the company underestimates the amount of prepaid expense to be recognized, it would understate the expenses for the current period, leading to an overstatement of net income. In future periods, when the correct amount of expense is recognized, net income would be understated.

That’s a solid understanding of how an underestimation impacts financial statements! It demonstrates you grasp the ripple effect of errors across periods. 

To push your thinking a bit further, let's consider the impact on the balance sheet. How would *underestimating* the prepaid expense affect the reported value of total assets in the current period? Would it be an overstatement or understatement, and why?

If the company underestimates the prepaid expense, it would overstate the value of prepaid assets on the balance sheet because less of the prepaid amount would be moved to expense, leaving more in the asset account.

The tables lack header rows. The two visual headings that exist, “Assignment” and “Maximum Grade” are formatted with the Bold button on the Word ribbon instead of making them into a Table Header Row through Table Properties. This is a recreation of a real example I spotted in a course! Remember to avoid blank table cells also. An interactive or media element has been excluded from this version of the text. You can view it online here: https://pressbooks.ulib.csuohio.edu/accessibility/?p=180 3.11: Building a Fluid Container for Content in Blackboard Earlier we talked about using relative units such as em and % for font size and image width to create content that scales when a user changes her font size in her browser, or content that reflows when the user changes the browser window size. This same principle applies to HTML containers. In HTML, there is a generic type of container element, called a Div, that we can use to surround our content. It has an opening
tag before the content, and a closing
tag at the end of the content. When we specify a width in percent (%) for a container, its content will reflow as a browser window is scaled down. In the past, people used tables to layout just about everything on a web page. While this works for sighted users, it causes problems for people using screen readers. Using tables for layout should be reserved for tabular data or information that has a two-way relationship, such as found in rubrics or course schedules. Sometimes, tables can be used for layout if the content within is read in a logical order. A screen reader reads linearly, from top to bottom, line by line, in the order that content appears in the HTML. This holds true for both the content in the HTML code and content within a table. If the default language is read from left to right, the screen reader also reads from left to right, line by line, from top to bottom. Below I’ll give you some code to create fluid content containers. Their basic structure can be re-used and you can put your choice of text, images or media within. Single container with rounded corners Here’s a single container with rounded corners in which you can write whatever you would like. This box will respond to your screen size so that the text reflows and remains visible without scrolling, until Blackboard’s content area hits its minimum width of 1150 pixels. It doesn’t use an image in its background, so it is light weight in terms of downloading content. chat_history.content: Are tables always bad for accessibility?

That's a great question! It's not necessarily that tables are *always* bad, but they can *easily* become inaccessible if not constructed thoughtfully. What potential problems do you think might arise when someone using a screen reader encounters a poorly designed table?
A screen reader might not be able to interpret the data correctly, leading to confusion.

That’s a good start. Can you elaborate on *why* a screen reader might struggle with a table’s data? Think about how a sighted person visually scans a table to understand the relationships between the data – what information does a screen reader user *need* to understand those same relationships?

A screen reader user needs to understand the structure of the table, such as which cells are headers and which are data cells. Without proper headers and table structures, the relationships between data points can become unclear.

You’re absolutely right – identifying headers and data cells is crucial. But let’s go a bit deeper. Imagine a complex table with multiple levels of headers (like a table summarizing sales data by region, then by product category, then by month). How might a screen reader convey that multi-level relationship to a user so they can understand which data belongs to which category?

A screen reader can use nested headers to convey multi-level relationships. Each level of the header can be announced as the user navigates through the table, helping them understand the context of the data. For example, it might say "Region: North, Product Category: Electronics, Month: January, Sales: $1000." This way, the user can follow the hierarchy and make sense of the data.

That’s a very clear and accurate explanation of how nested headers work! It sounds like you’ve grasped a key concept in accessible table design. 

Would you be interested in exploring some of the more advanced techniques for creating accessible tables, such as using the `scope` attribute or the `aria-describedby` attribute to provide additional context?
I'd love to learn more about the `scope` attribute and `aria-describedby` attribute.

Excellent! Let's start with the `scope` attribute. Imagine a simple table with a header row and a data row. How do you think specifying the `scope` attribute for the header cells (e.g., `<th scope="col">` or `<th scope="row">`) helps a screen reader user understand which data cells each header applies to?

The `scope` attribute helps a screen reader user understand which data cells each header applies to by explicitly defining whether a header cell applies to a column (`scope="col"`) or a row (`scope="row"`). This makes it clear to the screen reader which data belongs under each header, improving the overall accessibility of the table.

That’s a solid understanding of how the `scope` attribute works! It essentially provides semantic information that helps the screen reader create the correct associations between headers and data. 

Now, let’s consider a slightly more complex scenario. What if a table has both row and column headers? How would you use the `scope` attribute in that situation to ensure the screen reader accurately conveys the relationships between all the headers and data cells?

In a table with both row and column headers, you would use the `scope` attribute for both the row headers (`scope="row"`) and the column headers (`scope="col"`). This way, the screen reader can accurately convey the relationships between all the headers and data cells, ensuring that users understand which data belongs to which row and column headers. For example, a cell in the table might be announced as "Region: North, Product Category: Electronics, Sales: $1000," clearly indicating the intersection of the row and column headers. Thank you for the help.

Reductive Elimination Reactions

Reductive elimination is the microscopic reverse of oxidative addition. The reductive elimination can only occur when the two ligands to be eliminated are in cis-position.

For instance the previously discussed oxidative cis-addition of H2 to the iridium complex is reversible, and the reverse is called the reductive elimination (Fig. \(1\)). The cis-orientation of the two hydrido ligands is necessary to form an H-H bond. The reaction can be thought of going along a reaction path in which the Ir-H bonds become gradually larger and and the H-H distance gradually smaller until the H2 molecule is eliminated from the complex.

During reductive elimination, the electrons in the M–X bond head toward ligand Y, and the electrons in M–Y head to the metal. The eliminating ligands are always X-type! On the whole, the oxidation state of the metal decreases by two units, two new open coordination sites become available, and an X–Y bond forms. What does the change in oxidation state suggest about changes in electron density at the metal? As suggested by the name “reductive,” the metal gains electrons. The ligands lose electrons as the new X–Y bond cannot possibly be polarized to both X and Y, as the original M–X and M–Y bonds were. Using these ideas, you may already be thinking about reactivity trends in reductive elimination…hold that thought.

It’s been observed in a number of cases that a ligand dissociates from octahedral complexes before concerted reductive elimination occurs. Presumably, dissociation to form a distorted TBP geometry brings the eliminating groups closer to one another to facilitate elimination.

Square planar complexes may either take on an additional fifth ligand or lose a ligand to form an odd-coordinate complex before reductive elimination. Direct reductive elimination without dissociation or association is possible, too.

Reactivity trends in reductive elimination are opposite those of oxidative addition. More electron-rich ligands bearing electron-donating groups react more rapidly, since the ligands lose electron density as the reaction proceeds. More electron-poor metal centers—bearing π-acidic ligands and/or ligands with electron-withdrawing groups—react more rapidly, since the metal center gains electrons. Sterically bulky ancillary ligands promote reductive elimination since the release of X and Y can “ease” steric strain in the starting complex. Steric hindrance helps explain, for example, why coordination of a fifth ligand to a square planar complex promotes reductive elimination even though coordination increases electron density at the metal center. A second example: trends in rates of reductive eliminations of alkanes parallel the steric demands of the eliminating ligands: C–C > C–H > H–H.

Mechanistic trends for reductive elimination actually parallel trends in mechanisms of oxidative addition, since these two reactions are the microscopic reverse of one another. Non-polar and moderately pol

chat_history.content: Is reductive elimination only possible when the ligands are in trans-position?

That's a great question! It gets to the heart of understanding how reductive elimination happens. What about the geometry of the complex do you think *allows* the metal center to effectively lose those ligands in a concerted fashion?
The ligands need to be in cis-position to facilitate reductive elimination. This allows for the formation of a new bond between the ligands as they are eliminated from the metal center.

That's a much more accurate understanding! So, if the ligands *need* to be cis for this to happen, what implications does that have for the design of catalysts intended to perform reductive elimination?

The catalyst design should prioritize the ability to bring the ligands into a cis configuration to facilitate reductive elimination. This could involve selecting ligands that favor cis arrangements or designing the catalyst to undergo conformational changes that place the ligands in the necessary positions.

That’s a very insightful point about catalyst design! Considering that achieving the correct geometry is crucial, what challenges might arise in maintaining that cis configuration throughout the catalytic cycle, especially under reaction conditions?

The challenges might include steric hindrance, ligand exchange dynamics, and the stability of the cis configuration under varying temperatures and pressures. These factors could lead to ligand dissociation or rearrangement, preventing effective reductive elimination.

You've identified some excellent practical hurdles! Thinking beyond just *static* geometry, how might a catalyst be designed to *actively promote* and maintain that crucial cis configuration, even in the face of those disruptive forces?

The catalyst could be designed with flexible ligands that can adapt to maintain the cis configuration under different conditions. Additionally, incorporating sterically demanding ligands could help stabilize the cis arrangement by preventing ligand dissociation or rearrangement. Another approach could be using bidentate or multidentate ligands that can chelate the metal center, enforcing the cis geometry and reducing the likelihood of ligand exchange.

Those are all excellent strategies for enforcing cis geometry! Considering that steric bulk can be a powerful tool, but also a potential hindrance, how might you balance the need for steric protection of the cis configuration with the need to allow substrate access to the metal center for reactivity?

To balance steric protection and substrate access, the catalyst could use ligands with tunable steric bulk. For example, using ligands with adjustable substituents or flexible backbones could allow for fine-tuning of the steric environment around the metal center. Additionally, incorporating ligands with different electronic properties could help modulate the reactivity of the metal center, making it more selective for the desired reductive elimination pathway. Now, I think I have a good understanding of the topic. Thank you for the help.

Thumbnail: The Aksum Obelisk) in Aksum (Tigray Region, Ethiopia). Image used wtih permission (CC BY 2.5 Generic; Ondřej Žváček via Wikipedia). 

09: African History to 1500 

200,000 – 100,000 BP (Before Present) First behaviorally modern human emerged in Africa

c. 7000 BCE Beginnings of the Agricultural Revolution in Africa

c. 3000 BCE – 1500 CE The Bantu expansions

900s BCE Rule of Queen Makeda (Ethiopia)

c. 800 BCE – 300 CE Kingdom of Da’amat (Ethiopia)

c. 250 BCE Founding of Djenne-Jeno, one of Africa’s first cities (Western Sudan)

c. 100 – 950 CE The Empire of Aksum

c. 300 CE Ghana emerged as a state (Western Sudan)

c. 325 – 350 CE The rule of King Ezana (Aksum/Ethiopia)

c. 800 CE Ghana became an empire (Western Sudan)

1000 – 1500 CE Height of Swahili society (East Africa)

1200 – 1450 CE Height of Great Zimbabwe (southern Africa/ Zimbabwe Plateau)

1235 CE Sundiata Keita founded the Mali Empire (Western Sudan)

1324 – 1325 CE Mansa Musa performed the hajj (Western Sudan)

Early 1400s CE Portuguese began to explore the Atlantic coast of West Africa; beginnings of the Age of Exploration

1460s CE Sunni Ali built the Songhai Empire (Western Sudan)

1493 – 1528 CE Askia the Great ruled during the Golden Age of the Songhai Empire (Western Sudan)

Early 1500s CE The Portuguese built a Trading Post Empire in the Indian Ocean (East Africa)

1591 CE Moroccans invaded the Songhai Empire (Western Sudan)

1699 CE The Omanis (allied with some Swahili rulers) seized Swahili city-states from the Portuguese (East Africa)

9.02: Introduction

Adventurously sailing the Indian Ocean in the early 1500s CE, Duarte Barbosa, a Portuguese naval officer, was confident that he was helping to forge a new, enduring era of Portuguese dominance. As he passed through several Swahili city-states on the East African coast, Barbosa noted the brisk trade and the riches of these African settlements where he saw a “great plenty of gold” that would serve Portuguese interests.1 In his mind, God had destined these stashes of gold for the Portuguese and the local Swahili rulers acted unwisely and arrogantly to defend themselves. In the conflict that followed, the Portuguese plundered the Swahili city-states, burning buildings and enslaving African men and women. Barbosa boasted that when the Portuguese looted the settlements, they slaughtered many people and took a “great spoil of gold and silver and goods.”2 Barbosa’s description highlights the violence of Portuguese conquest and also his expectation that he and his countrymen were creating a new Portuguese empire that would make a lasting mark in East Africa and the wider Indian Ocean world. However, less than 100 years later, Portuguese influences were noticeably absent in most of East Africa and their power in the Indian Ocean was fading rapidly. Barbosa, himself, had traveled with his brother-in-law, Ferdinand Magellan, and met an untimely end (in his early 40s) in the Philippines.

Writing about the coast of East A

chat_history.content: Did the Portuguese only trade peacefully with the Swahili city-states?
That's a great question! It gets at a complex relationship. What makes you ask whether the Portuguese *only* traded peacefully? What might suggest there was more than just trade happening?

The Portuguese were driven by a desire for control of the spice trade and sought to establish monopolies, which often led to conflicts. They built forts and trading posts to secure their interests, which could have been seen as aggressive by the Swahili.

That’s a very insightful connection! If the Swahili perceived these forts and trading posts as aggressive, how might they have responded, and what evidence suggests whether that response was peaceful or not?

The Swahili might have responded with resistance or even military action. Evidence of conflicts, such as the Battle of Diu in 1509, where the Portuguese defeated a combined fleet of Egyptian Mamluks, Indians, and Swahili, suggests that the interactions were not always peaceful.

That’s excellent – you’ve pinpointed a key event demonstrating conflict. Considering the Battle of Diu involved multiple parties, how do you think the Portuguese actions specifically impacted the Swahili city-states, beyond simply being caught in a larger conflict?

The Portuguese actions likely disrupted the established trade networks of the Swahili city-states, leading to economic decline and social unrest. The Portuguese might have imposed their own trade practices and taxes, further straining relations. Additionally, the presence of Portuguese forts could have been seen as a direct threat to Swahili sovereignty and independence.

You’ve identified several ways the Portuguese presence could have destabilized Swahili city-states. If the Swahili were experiencing economic decline and a loss of sovereignty, what specific strategies might they have employed – beyond outright military confrontation – to resist Portuguese influence or mitigate its negative effects?

The Swahili might have sought alliances with other regional powers to counterbalance Portuguese influence. They could have also adapted their trade routes and practices to avoid Portuguese-controlled areas, perhaps by strengthening ties with the Ottoman Empire or other Muslim trading networks. Additionally, the Swahili might have focused on fortifying their cities and improving their military capabilities to better defend against Portuguese aggression.

The Brownian motion model we described above was for a single character. However, we often want to consider more than one character at once. This requires the use of multivariate models. The situation is more complex than the univariate case – but not much! In this section I will derive the expectation for a set of (potentially correlated) traits evolving together under a multivariate Brownian motion model.

Character values across species can covary because of phylogenetic relationships, because different characters tend to evolve together, or both. Fortunately, we can generalize the model described above to deal with both of these types of covariation. To do this, we must combine two variance-covariance matrices. The first one, C, we have already seen; it describes the variances and covariances across species for single traits due to shared evolutionary history along the branches of a phylogentic tree. The second variance-covariance matrix, which we can call R, describes the variances and covariances across traits due to their tendencies to evolve together. For example, if a species of lizard gets larger due to the action of natural selection, then many of its other traits, like head and limb size, will get larger too due to allometry. The diagonal entries of the matrix R will provide our estimates of σi2, the net rate of evolution, for each trait, while off-diagonal elements, σij, represent evolutionary covariances between pairs of traits. We will denote number of species as n and the number of traits as m, so that C is n × n and R is m × m.

Our multivariate model of evolution has parameters that can be described by an m × 1 vector, a, containing the starting values for each trait – $\bar{z}_1(0)$, $\bar{z}_2(0)$, and so on, up to $\bar{z}_m(0)$, and an m × m matrix, R, described above. This model has m parameters for a and m ⋅ (m + 1)/2 parameters for R, for a total of m ⋅ (m + 3)/2 parameters.

Under our multivariate Brownian motion model, the joint distribution of all traits across all species still follows a multivariate normal distribution. We find the variance-covariance matrix that describes all characters across all species by combining the two matrices R and C into a single large matrix using the Kroeneker product:

$\textbf{V} = \textbf{R} ⊗ \textbf{C} \label{3.23}$

This matrix V is n ⋅ m × n ⋅ m, and describes the variances and covariances of all traits across all species.

We can return to our example of evolution along a single branch (Figure 3.4a). Imagine that we have two characters that are evolving under a multivariate Brownian motion model. We state the parameters of the model as:

$\begin{array}{lcr} \mathbf{a} = \begin{bmatrix} \bar{z}_1(0) \ \bar{z}_2(0) \ \end{bmatrix} \ \mathbf{R} = \begin{bmatrix} \sigma_1^2 & \sigma_{12} \ \sigma_{12} & \sigma_2^2 \ \end{bmatrix} \ \end{array} \label{3.24}$

For a single branch, C = [t1], so:

chat_history.content: Does the multivariate Brownian motion model only consider independent traits?

That’s a good question! What makes you ask whether it *only* considers independent traits? Perhaps thinking about what the model *would* look like if traits *weren’t* independent could help clarify your thinking.
I think that if traits weren't independent, there would be some kind of correlation between them.

That’s a very insightful observation! Could you explain how this correlation would manifest itself *within* the multivariate Brownian motion model – specifically, how would it change the way the different traits evolve over time relative to each other?

The correlation between traits would be represented by the variance-covariance matrix, which captures how the traits co-vary. This matrix would influence the joint distribution of traits, showing how changes in one trait might affect another.

That’s a great connection! So, if the variance-covariance matrix indicates a positive correlation, what does that tell you about the *direction* of change in the correlated traits – do they tend to move in the same direction, opposite directions, or is there no predictable relationship?

If the variance-covariance matrix indicates a positive correlation, it means that the traits tend to move in the same direction. A negative correlation would imply that they move in opposite directions.

Excellent! You’ve clearly grasped how correlation is represented and interpreted within the multivariate Brownian motion model. Now, considering that the model describes *random* movements, does a positive correlation mean the traits will *always* move in the same direction, or is it more about the *probability* of them moving together?
A positive correlation means that there is a higher probability that the traits will move in the same direction, but it does not guarantee that they will always do so.
That’s a crucial distinction! If correlation implied certainty, what would that mean for the “Brownian” or random aspect of the motion?
If correlation implied certainty, the motion wouldn't be truly Brownian or random, as the traits would always move together in a predictable way.

You’ve pinpointed a key aspect of how randomness and correlation interact. Now, let’s think a bit more broadly. How might incorporating correlated traits into the multivariate Brownian motion model be useful in modeling real-world phenomena, compared to assuming complete independence?

Incorporating correlated traits allows for a more accurate representation of real-world phenomena, where traits often evolve together due to shared genetic or environmental influences. This can provide deeper insights into evolutionary processes and help predict how traits might co-evolve.

That’s a very insightful point about shared influences! Can you think of a specific example of traits that might co-evolve in this way, and how modeling their correlation would improve the accuracy of a Brownian motion model compared to treating them as independent?

In the context of animal morphology, traits like leg length and body size might co-evolve. Modeling their correlation would improve accuracy by accounting for the fact that changes in body size often influence leg length, rather than treating them as independent traits.

That’s a great example! Now, considering that the correlation itself might change over time, how could the multivariate Brownian motion model be extended to accommodate *dynamic* correlations between traits?

The model could be extended by allowing the variance-covariance matrix to change over time, reflecting evolving relationships between traits. This would involve incorporating time-dependent parameters into the matrix, enabling the model to capture shifts in correlations as traits co-evolve.

That’s a sophisticated idea! But simply allowing the variance-covariance matrix to change over time doesn’t fully address the challenge. What factors might *cause* these correlations to change, and how could those factors be incorporated into the model itself – beyond just letting the parameters shift?

The factors that cause these correlations to change could be environmental changes, genetic mutations, or selective pressures. These factors could be incorporated into the model by introducing additional variables or stochastic processes that influence the variance-covariance matrix over time. This would make the model more dynamic and better reflect the complexities of real-world trait evolution. Now I understand the concept of multivariate Brownian motion and how it differs from univariate Brownian motion. Thank you so much for the help.

seed.source_content:
Prostaglandins were first discovered and isolated from human semen in the 1930s by Ulf von Euler of Sweden. Thinking they had come from the prostate gland, he named them prostaglandins. It has since been determined that they exist and are synthesized in virtually every cell of the body. Prostaglandins, are like hormones in that they act as chemical messengers, but do not move to other sites, but work right within the cells where they are synthesized.

Introduction

Prostaglandins are unsaturated carboxylic acids, consisting of of a 20 carbon skeleton that also contains a five member ring. They are biochemically synthesized from the fatty acid, arachidonic acid. See the graphic on the left. The unique shape of the arachidonic acid caused by a series of cis double bonds helps to put it into position to make the five member ring.

Structure of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2)

Prostaglandin Structure

Prostaglandins are unsaturated carboxylic acids, consisting of of a 20 carbon skeleton that also contains a five member ring and are based upon the fatty acid, arachidonic acid. There are a variety of structures one, two, or three double bonds. On the five member ring there may also be double bonds, a ketone, or alcohol groups. A typical structure is on the left graphic.

Functions of Prostaglandins

There are a variety of physiological effects including:

1. Activation of the inflammatory response, production of pain, and fever. When tissues are damaged, white blood cells flood to the site to try to minimize tissue destruction. Prostaglandins are produced as a result.
2. Blood clots form when a blood vessel is damaged. A type of prostaglandin called thromboxane stimulates constriction and clotting of platelets. Conversely, PGI2, is produced to have the opposite effect on the walls of blood vessels where clots should not be forming.
3. Certain prostaglandins are involved with the induction of labor and other reproductive processes. PGE2 causes uterine contractions and has been used to induce labor.
4. Prostaglandins are involved in several other organs such as the gastrointestinal tract (inhibit acid synthesis and increase secretion of protective mucus), increase blood flow in kidneys, and leukotriens promote constriction of bronchi associated with asthma.

Ball-and-stick model of the aspirin molecule, as found in the solid state. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data from Kim, Y.; Machida, K.; Taga, T.; Osaki, K. (1985). "Structure Redetermination and Packing Analysis of Aspirin Crystal". Chem. Pharm. Bull. 33 (7): 2641-2647. ISSN 1347-5223.

Effects of Aspirin and other Pain Killers

When you see that prostaglandins induce inflammation, pain, and fever, what comes to mind but aspirin. Aspirin blocks an enzyme called cyclooxygenase, COX-1 and COX-2, which is involved with the ring closure and addition of oxygen to arachidonic acid converting to prostaglandins. The acetyl group on aspirin is hydrolzed and then bonded to the alcohol group of serine as an ester.

chat_history.content: Does aspirin work by increasing the production of prostaglandins?

That's a common misconception! Actually, aspirin *decreases* the production of prostaglandins. But that's getting ahead of ourselves. What do you already know about prostaglandins and their role in the body – perhaps what problems might arise if you *didn't* have enough of them?

Prostaglandins are lipid compounds derived from fatty acids, particularly arachidonic acid. They are involved in various physiological processes, including inflammation, blood flow, and the regulation of gastrointestinal secretions. If there weren't enough prostaglandins, it could lead to issues like reduced protection of the stomach lining and impaired regulation of blood flow.

That’s a solid understanding of prostaglandins and their functions! Now, considering their role in inflammation, how might *decreasing* their production be beneficial in certain situations – for example, when you have a headache or muscle aches?
Decreasing prostaglandin production can reduce inflammation and pain, which is why aspirin and other NSAIDs are effective for headaches and muscle aches.

That’s right! So, if decreasing prostaglandin production relieves symptoms, what do you think might be happening at a *cellular* level to cause those symptoms in the first place? Think about what prostaglandins *do* – how might their normal function contribute to pain or inflammation?

Prostaglandins promote inflammation and pain by increasing blood flow to the affected area and sensitizing pain receptors. When tissues are damaged, arachidonic acid is released and converted into prostaglandins, which mediate the inflammatory response.

That’s a very insightful explanation! Now, considering that aspirin decreases prostaglandin production, can you explain *how* aspirin interferes with the process you just described – specifically, what enzyme does aspirin target to achieve this effect?

Aspirin inhibits the cyclooxygenase (COX) enzyme, which is responsible for converting arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. By blocking COX, aspirin reduces the production of prostaglandins, thereby decreasing inflammation and pain. Thanks for the help.

seed.source_content:
Learning Objective
1. Learn how a change in the price level affects the equilibrium interest rate.

Now let’s consider the effects of a price level increase in the money market. When the price level rises in an economy, the average price of all goods and services sold is increasing. Inflation is calculated as the percentage increase in a country’s price level over some period, usually a year. This means that in the period during which the price level increases, inflation is occurring. Thus studying the effects of a price level increase is the same as studying the effects of inflation.

Inflation can arise for several reasons that will be discussed later in this chapter. For now, we will imagine that the price level increases for some unspecified reason and consider the consequences.

Suppose the money market is originally in equilibrium at point A in Figure 7.10.1 with real money supply \(M^{S}/P_{\$}’\) and interest rate \(i_{\$}’\). Suppose the price level increases, ceteris paribus. Again, the ceteris paribus assumption means that we assume all other exogenous variables in the model remain fixed at their original levels. In this exercise, it means that the money supply (\(M^{S}\)) and real GDP (\(Y_{\$}\)) remain fixed. An increase in the price level (\(P_{\$}\)) causes a decrease in the real money supply (\(M^{S}/P_{\$}\)) since \(M_{S}\) remains constant. In the adjoining diagram, this is shown as a shift from \(M^{S}/P_{\$}’\) to \(M^{S}/P_{\$}^″\). At the original interest rate, \(i_{\$}’\), the real money supply has fallen to level 2 along the horizontal axis, while real money demand remains at level 1. This means that money demand exceeds money supply and the actual interest rate is lower than the new equilibrium rate. Adjustment to the higher interest rate will follow the “interest rate too low” equilibrium story.

More intuition concerning these effects arises if one recalls that price level increases will increase the transactions demand for money. In this version, nominal money demand will exceed nominal money supply and set off the same adjustment process described in the previous paragraph.

The final equilibrium will occur at point B on the diagram. The real money supply will have fallen from level 1 to level 2 while the equilibrium interest rate has risen from \(i_{\$}'\) to \(i_{\$}^″\). Thus an increase in the price level (i.e., inflation) will cause an increase in average interest rates in an economy. In contrast, a decrease in the price level (deflation) will cause a decrease in average interest rates in an economy.

Key Takeaways
• An increase in the price level (i.e., inflation), ceteris paribus, will cause an increase in average interest rates in an economy. In contrast, a decrease in the price level (deflation), ceteris paribus, will cause a decrease in average interest rates in an economy.

chat_history.content: Does an increase in the price level lead to a decrease in the equilibrium interest rate?
That's a great question, touching on a core concept in macroeconomics! To start, how do you think changes in the price level might affect the demand for money?
An increase in the price level would increase the demand for money because people need more money to buy the same amount of goods and services.
That's a good start! But does an increase in the *demand* for money automatically lead to an increase or decrease in the equilibrium interest rate? Why?

An increase in the demand for money would lead to an increase in the equilibrium interest rate because the supply of money is fixed in the short run. This is because the interest rate is the price of money, and when demand increases, the price (interest rate) must rise to balance the market.

You've connected the increase in money demand to a rise in interest rates, which is a logical step. However, let's revisit the initial question: Does an *increase* in the price level lead to a *decrease* in the equilibrium interest rate? Does your current explanation align with that initial proposition? Why or why not?

I see the contradiction now. An increase in the price level increases the demand for money, which should increase the equilibrium interest rate, not decrease it. So, the initial proposition seems incorrect based on this analysis.

You've successfully identified the inconsistency! It seems you've grasped the relationship between price levels, money demand, and interest rates. 

Would you like to explore *why* the initial proposition might be misleading, perhaps by considering the factors that *could* lead to a decrease in interest rates despite an increase in the price level?
I would like to explore the factors that could lead to a decrease in interest rates despite an increase in the price level.

Excellent! To begin, can you think of any factors, independent of the price level, that could exert downward pressure on interest rates? Consider both demand and supply side influences on the market for money.

A decrease in the money supply by the central bank could lead to a decrease in interest rates despite an increase in the price level. Additionally, a decrease in the demand for money due to increased use of credit or other financial instruments could also exert downward pressure on interest rates.

Those are both excellent points! You're correctly identifying factors that shift the supply and demand curves for money. 

Now, let's consider a scenario where the price level *and* the money supply both increase simultaneously. How might that affect the equilibrium interest rate, and what would determine the *net* effect? Would it be possible for the interest rate to remain unchanged, or even decrease, despite the higher price level?

If the money supply increases at the same rate as the price level, the real money supply remains unchanged. In this case, the equilibrium interest rate would also remain unchanged. However, if the money supply increases more than the price level, the real money supply increases, which would lead to a decrease in the equilibrium interest rate. So, it is possible for the interest rate to decrease despite an increase in the price level if the money supply increases sufficiently.

That's a very thorough and accurate explanation! You've demonstrated a strong understanding of how changes in both the price level and money supply interact to determine interest rates. 

To push your understanding even further, let's consider the role of expectations. How might *anticipated* inflation (an expectation of a future price level increase) affect the nominal interest rate, and how does that differ from the impact of an *unexpected* increase in the price level?

If inflation is anticipated, the nominal interest rate would likely increase to compensate for the expected decrease in the purchasing power of money. This is because lenders would demand a higher interest rate to offset the anticipated erosion of their principal due to inflation. In contrast, an unexpected increase in the price level might initially lead to a temporary decrease in the real interest rate, as the nominal interest rate adjusts more slowly to changes in inflation. However, over time, the nominal interest rate would adjust to reflect the new inflation expectations, leading to an increase in the nominal interest rate. Thank you for the help.

seed.source_content:
Learning Objectives
1. Explain what a value proposition is.
2. Understand why a company may develop different value propositions for different target markets.

What Is a Value Proposition?

Individual buyers and organizational buyers both evaluate products and services to see if they provide desired benefits. For example, when you’re exploring your vacation options, you want to know the benefits of each destination and the value you will get by going to each place. Before you (or a firm) can develop a strategy or create a strategic plan, you first have to develop a value proposition. A value proposition is a thirty-second “elevator speech” stating the specific benefits a product or service offering provides a buyer. It shows why the product or service is superior to competing offers. The value proposition answers the questions, “Why should I buy from you or why should I hire you?” As such, the value proposition becomes a critical component in shaping strategy.

The following is an example of a value proposition developed by a sales consulting firm: “Our clients grow their business, large or small, typically by a minimum of 30–50% over the previous year. They accomplish this without working 80 hour weeks and sacrificing their personal lives” (Lake, 2009).

Note that although a value proposition will hopefully lead to profits for a firm, when the firm presents its value proposition to its customers, it doesn’t mention its own profits. That’s because the goal is to focus on the external market or what customers want.

Firms typically segment markets and then identify different target markets, or groups of customers, they want to reach when they are developing their value propositions. Target markets will be discussed in more detail in Chapter 5. For now, be aware that companies sometimes develop different value propositions for different target markets just as individuals may develop a different value proposition for different employers. The value proposition tells each group of customers (or potential employers) why they should buy a product or service, vacation to a particular destination, donate to an organization, hire you, and so forth.

Once the benefits of a product or service are clear, the firm must develop strategies that support the value proposition. The value proposition serves as a guide for this process. In the case of our sales consulting firm, the strategies it develops must help clients improve their sales by 30–50 percent. Likewise, if a company’s value proposition states that the firm is the largest retailer in the region with the most stores and best product selection, opening stores or increasing the firm’s inventory might be a key part of the company’s strategy. Looking at Amazon’s value proposition, “Low price, wide selection with added convenience anytime, anywhere,” one can easily see how Amazon has been so successful1.

Individuals and students should also develop their own personal value propositions. Tell companies why t

chat_history.content: What is the purpose of a value proposition?
That's a great question! In your own words, what problem does a strong value proposition aim to solve for a customer?
A strong value proposition aims to solve the problem of customer uncertainty by clearly communicating the unique benefits and value that a product or service offers.

That's a solid start! But let's dig a little deeper. If simply *stating* benefits solved customer uncertainty, wouldn't all marketing materials be equally effective? What makes a value proposition truly *compelling* and differentiates it from just a list of features?

A compelling value proposition addresses the specific needs and pain points of the target customer, showing how the product or service solves their problems better than alternatives. It's about making a clear, persuasive argument for why the customer should choose your offering.

That’s a very insightful point! So, if a value proposition is about solving specific customer problems *better* than the alternatives, how would you go about identifying those key problems and tailoring your proposition to address them directly?

I would start by conducting market research to understand the target audience's needs, preferences, and challenges. Then, I would analyze competitors to see how they are addressing these issues and identify gaps that our value proposition can fill. By combining this information, we can create a value proposition that clearly communicates the unique benefits and advantages of our product or service, making it stand out in the market.

That’s a comprehensive approach to crafting a value proposition. But let's consider this: market research and competitor analysis provide data, but don’t necessarily reveal *emotional* drivers. How might understanding a customer’s aspirations, fears, or deeply held beliefs strengthen a value proposition beyond simply addressing practical needs?

Understanding emotional drivers can make a value proposition more relatable and compelling. For example, if a customer aspires to feel secure, a value proposition that emphasizes reliability and trustworthiness can resonate more deeply. Similarly, addressing fears, such as the fear of missing out or the fear of failure, can make the value proposition more persuasive. By tapping into these emotional drivers, a value proposition can create a stronger connection with the customer and differentiate the offering in a meaningful way. Now, I think I have a good understanding of the value proposition. Thank you so much for the help.

seed.source_content:
Intent Increase confidence in changes by regularly rebuilding the system.

Problem

How do you convince your customer that you are on the right path?

This problem is difficult because:

• It can be hard to demo a software system under development, or to discuss problems with users since there is often no stable, running version of the system available.

• Integrating changes from multiple versions of a system can be slow and painful.

Yet, solving this problem is feasible because:

• You don’t have to wait until a component is “finished” before integrating it.

Solution

Institute a discipline of integrating new changes and developments on a daily basis.

Steps

• Have version management and configuration management systems in place.

• Make sure you have regression tests in place for the parts you are working on.

• Institute a discipline of short transactions for checking out system components and checking them back in again. Plan iterations to be as short as possible to allow changes to be integrated into a running system.

Tradeoffs

Pros

• You always have a working version to demo.

• You can always have a working version to run your regression tests.

• You can quickly validate your changes, thereby helping you to Build Confidence.

Cons

• You must continuously integrate changes.

Difficulties

• Large systems may have very long build times. You may need to rearchitect the system first to enable shorter build times.

• It can be hard to break some kinds of large modifications into meaningful updates that can be individually integrated.

Rationale

Many practitioners advocate a process of continuous integration as a way to avoid a risky and painful big-bang integration [Boo94].

Related Patterns

Regression Test After Every Change minimizes the risk of defects creeping in during integration.

Continuous Integration [Boo94] [Bec00] is a proven way to Always Have a Running Version.

7.07: Regression Test After Every Change

Intent Build confidence by making sure that whatever worked before still works.

Problems

How can you be sure that the last change you made won’t break the system?

This problem is difficult because:

• In a complex system, small changes can have unexpected side effects. A seemingly innocuous change may break something without this being immediately discovered.

Yet, solving this problem is feasible because:

• You have written test suites that express how the system should behave.

Solution

Run your regression test suite every time you think you have reached a stable state.

Tradeoffs

Pros

• It is easier to Always Have a Running Version.

• It is easier to Build Confidence as you proceed.

Cons

• You must relentlessly write the tests.

Difficulties

• The legacy system may not have adequate regression tests defined. To enable evolution, you will have to Grow Your Test Base Incrementally.
• Tests can only show that defects are present, not that they are absent. You may have failed to test precisely the aspect that y

chat_history.content: Is it possible to convince the customer that you are on the right path without having a stable, running version of the system?
That's a really interesting challenge! What aspects of "being on the right path" do you think are most important to a customer who hasn't *seen* a working system?

I think the customer would want to see progress and evidence that the development team is addressing their needs. They might look for regular updates, demonstrations of key features, and assurances that issues are being tracked and resolved.
Those all seem like very reasonable expectations. Thinking about those demonstrations of key features – even if not fully integrated – what form could those take *without* a fully running system?

Mockups, prototypes, or even detailed design documents could serve as evidence of progress. These artifacts can show the customer that development is moving forward and that their requirements are being considered.

That's a great start. But consider this: how confident would a customer *really* be in mockups or design documents if they couldn't interact with *anything*? What crucial element might be missing from those static representations?

The crucial element missing from static representations is the ability to see the system in action and verify that it works as expected. This is where continuous integration comes into play, ensuring that there is always a stable, running version of the system available for demonstration and testing.

You've touched on a key point – the value of seeing something *work*. But let's push that a little further. Even with continuous integration, early versions are often incomplete or buggy. What specific *types* of demonstrable progress, short of a fully functional system, could build confidence even with imperfections?

Regression testing can help build customer confidence by showing that new changes haven't broken existing functionality. This way, even if the system isn't fully complete, customers can see that it remains stable and reliable as it evolves.

That's a solid point about regression testing demonstrating stability. But consider the customer's perspective: seeing tests *pass* is somewhat abstract. What if, instead of focusing on what *doesn't* break, you could show them something *new* working, even if it's a small piece of the overall system?

Incremental delivery of features can build customer confidence by showing tangible progress. Even small, working features can demonstrate that the development team is making headway and addressing customer needs. This approach allows customers to see the system evolving in a controlled and reliable manner. Thanks for the help.

Learning Objectives
• Find principal square roots and their opposites.
• Approximate square roots and find exact roots with a calculator.

Introduction

You have probably dealt with the roots of plants and trees when gardening, but did you know that there are roots in mathematics, too?

Yes, roots do exist in math. The most common root is the square root. Let’s take a look at what roots are, how they relate to exponents, and how you find the square root of a number.

Squares and Roots

To help understand square roots, let’s review some facts about exponents. Look at the table below.

Exponent Name Expanded Form
$\ 3^{2}$

“Three squared”

“Three to the second power”

$\ 3 \cdot 3$
$\ 4^{5}$

“Four to the fifth power”

“Four to the fifth”

"Four raised to the power of five"

$\ 4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4$
$\ x^{3}$

“$\ x$ cubed”

“$\ x$ to the third power”

“$\ x$to the third”

$\ x \cdot x \cdot x$
$\ x^{n}$

“$\ x$ to the $\ n$ th power”

“$\ x$ to the $\ n$ th”

“$\ x$ to the power of $\ n$”

$\ x \cdot x \cdot x_{\ldots} \cdot x$ n times

You can think of exponential numbers as “repeated multiplication.”

Just as dividing is the inverse of multiplying, the inverse of raising a number to a power is taking the root of a number. The most common root (and the one you will be studying here) is called the square root. When you are trying to find the square root of a number (say, 25), you are trying to find a number that can be multiplied by itself to create that original number. In the case of 25, you can find that $\ 5 \cdot 5=25$, so 5 must be the square root.

The symbol for the square root is called a radical symbol and looks like this: $\ \sqrt{ \quad}$. The expression $\ \sqrt{25}$ is read “the square root of twenty-five” or “radical twenty-five.” The number that is written under the radical symbol is called the radicand. Take a look at the following table.

Radical Name Simplified Form
$\ \sqrt{36}$

“Square root of thirty-six”

“Radical thirty-six”

$\ \sqrt{36}=\sqrt{6 \cdot 6}=6$
$\ \sqrt{100}$

“Square root of one hundred”

“Radical one hundred”

$\ \sqrt{100}=\sqrt{10 \cdot 10}=10$
$\ \sqrt{225}$

“Square root of two hundred twenty-five”

“Radical two hundred twenty-five”

$\ \sqrt{225}=\sqrt{15 \cdot 15}=15$

Look at $\ \sqrt{25}$ again. You may realize that there is another value that, when multiplied by itself, also results in 25. That number is -5.

$\ \begin{array}{c} 5 \cdot 5=25 \ -5 \cdot-5=25 \end{array}$

By definition, the square root symbol always means to find the positive root, called the principal root. So while $\ 5 \cdot 5$ and $\ -5 \cdot-5$ both equal 25, only 5 is the principal root. You should also know that zero is special because it has only one square root: itself (since $\ 0 \cdot 0=0$).

If you know the principal square root, you can also find its opposite. (Recall that any number plus its opposite will equal 0. So, for instance, $\ a+(-a)=0$.) In the table below, notice that while $\ \sqrt{x}$ will give
